text:
University Place, east side, from 9th to 8th Streets, showing the Hotel Lafayette (formerly the Hotel Martin) on the S.E. corner of 9th Street. This hotel is composed of three houses believed to have been originally built about 1855. A Mr. Martin altered them into one unit and opened them in 1883 as the Hotel Martin. In March 1902, the Martin became the Hotel Lafayette. The Lafayette, under the ownership of Mr. Raymond Orteig, is a French hotel, as was the Hotel Martin. It is especially renowned for its restaurant. Twenty-one years after the date of this picture it will be linked to the Lindbergh non-stop flight from New York to Paris, which will win the award offered by Mr. Orteig, the proprietor.

April 18, 1906.

Brown Brothers.

University Place, east side, from 10th to 8th Streets, showing the University Place Presbyterian Church (1845) on the S.E. corner of 10th Street, and the Hotel Lafayette (formerly Hotel Martin) on the S.E. corner of 9th Street. The vacant lot on the N.E. corner of 10th Street was left by the demolition (since 1902) of 65 University Place (old No. 35) and 23 East 10th Street. This lot will remain vacant till nearly 1925, when a 6-story building will be erected on it.

April 18, 1906.

Brown Brothers.

University Place, north on east side, from 8th Street, showing old 31-33 East 8th Street (formerly 41-39 Clinton Place), the Hotel Lafayette (formerly Hotel Martin) on the S.E. corner of 9th Street, the newly erected Devonshire House on the S.E. corner of 10th Street (site of University Place Presbyterian Church, 1845-1927), and the Hotel Albert at and adjoining the S.E. corner of 11th Street. The newer part of the Albert is the 11-story building (about 1906) in the middle of the block.
The 11-story loft building on the N.E. corner of 11th Street, built after 1902, occupies the site of old Union Court, a little private street within the block.
February 12, 1928.
P. L. Sperr.

8th Street, west from 43 East 8th Street east of University Place, opposite the northern end of Greene Street.
The building on the S.E. corner of University Place used to be the Merck Building, erected about 1895, replacing three old residences facing 8th Street (then known as Clinton Place). West from University Place, on the south side, are old houses remodelled into apartments, owned by Sailors Snug Harbor; Beyond them towers One Fifth Avenue, on the S.E. corner, built around 1926. In the background may be seen the Sixth Avenue Elevated station, at the western end of 8th Street. In the right foreground may be seen shops of various kinds, on the north side of the street.

P. L. Sperr.
April 26, 1933.

(1)
University Place, west side, between 8th Street and Waverly Place, at the S.W. corner of Washington Mews, which is a little semi-private street running through the block to Fifth Ave., and chiefly lined with old stables remodelled into studio apartments.
May 24, 1933.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)
The same, from a slightly different angle, and showing the N.W. corner.
February 24, 1933.

P. L. Sperr.

(3)
The same as No. 2, from an altitude.
May 24, 1933.

P. L. Sperr.
